div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: WHITE AND COLOURED LABOUR
div.p: The seriousness of the economic problem which arises when Eastern and Western labour come into conflict was discussed in "Public Opinion" last week, especially' in relation to Japan and the United States. But the same problem is to the front in Australia and in South Africa. Take Australia-it has adopted A deliberate policy of exclusion for the Japanese. Mr. C-R W. Bean, of Sydney, writing to the " Spectator," says "A Western and Oriental race cannot live together in Australia. The resolve of Australians to keep their oountry white is of an intensity undreamed of in England." May there not he something, he asks, in the fact that "while the Briton who never meets the Oriental declares that East and West can live side by side, his own race wherever in the world it meets an Oriental people refuses to live si"P by side with it 1 The Englishman in India is the strongest case in point. "No one," he adds, "can deny the danger of an Oriental overflow. There are some three million odd whites in Australia inhabiting three million square miles. To the North,at its very gates, up to within a day's sail are eight hundred million Orientals.' The weakest point that I can see in the Australian case h in the moral problem. Have we, so few, a right to keep out these hordes and save Australia for ourselves f But then-Is it for ourselves or for the forty million white men to come after, and for the perpetuation of our race and the ideals we believe in, and, above all, for our children ? Are they to look to ns for a healthy home-or for that mixed horror f Senator Pulsford, commenting on this letter says that "no one would dream from reading it that Japan had actually made repeated offers to Australia to enter int4> some treaty or arrangement controlling the emigration of Japanese to Australia so as to secure to Australia everything she desired, and that Australia, instead of availing herself of the courteous offers made by Japan, preferred to deal With the whole subject of the restriction of immigration in a way which was clearly shown to be offen sive to the public spirit of the people of Japau." There are many in Australia, adds fh'e Senator, "who do view with doep regret tho fact that certain Australian legislation tonds to create Empire difficulties that more courteous methods would obviate." In the Transvaal the problem is compli cated by the fact that the antipathy to ooloured men in this oase means antipathy to members of the same Empire, for the coloured men who have invaded Natal ami the Transvaal, and whose ooming has been resisted, are Indiana Lord Selborne says there can be no mistaking the strength of the unanimous demand oi all sections of tho white oommunity iq the Transvaal for the passing of an Acl making Registration for Asiatics compulsory The oflensive part, however, of the Registration Act is that which provides for the identification of holders of certificates by means of fingerprint impressions. General Botha, it is said, will try and adopt some less dffensive means of registration. But at bottom the objection to the Asiatic in the Transvaal and Natal is economic. They take away business from the whites, and that is a ground of oftenoe.

LE COMMERCE DE LA GOMME
Le Journal de la Chambre de Commerce anglaise en Egypte donne les renseignments suivants sur l'exportation de la gomme ara- bique.
Les exportations de la gomme arabique se repartissent comme suit en 1906 :

Les forets d'arbres produissant la gomme arabique se trouvent daus la province de Kor- dofan, et aussi aux environs de Djedid, dans la province du Nil-Blanc. La recolte de la gomme par les indigenes est libre ; la seule taxe qui existe est l'impot preleve a Omdur- man. Cet impot varie selon la valeur de la gomme et s'elevait, l'annee derniere, a environ 2 sh. 5 d. pour 99 livres.
La saison de la recolte s'etend de decembre a mai.

Il y a deux sortes de gommes : l'une d'une couleur ambree, l'autre blanche ; la difference provient de ce que cette derniere a ete longue- ment expose a l'action directe du soleil, gene- ralement a Omduran. La melleure gomme et la production la plus importante arrivent du Kordofan.

La gomme recoltee est rapportee.aux villa- ges et vendue contre arget comptant par les indigenes a des courtiers soudanairs, a Dueim principalement ; de la, le produit est envoye par voie fluviale a Omdurman, qui est le mar- che principal de la gomme au Soudan. Elle y est reemballee, a destination des marches euro- peens, dans de solides doubles sacs contenant chacun 300 livres.

Au lieu de computer, comme c'est l'usage, 100 rotolis (99 livres) au cantar, les marchands d'Omdurman comptent 110 rotolis, ce poids ficif supplementaire couvrant toute perte pos- sible pendant le trajet.

Le cout du transport par bateau d'Omdur- man a Khartoum-Nord, inclus toutes depen- ses, varie de 2 1/2 a 5 deniers le cantar (99 li- vres) ; jusqu'a Port-Soudan, le fret est de 3 livres Sterling 5 sh. 8 d. la tonne de 1,000 ki- logrammes, avec une reduction de 10% pour un chargement de 10 tonnes.

De Port-Soudan, la gomme est transportee par vapeurs jusqu'a Suez, ou elle est souvent triee, puis transbordee soit a destination de l'Europe, de l'Amerique ou de l'Australie, soit embarquee sur chemin de fer pour le Caire ou Alexandrie.
Les principaux marches pour la gomme arabique sont Marseille, La Havre, Hainbourg, New-York, Loundres, Loverpool, Anvers, Bar- celone, Melbourne et Trieste.

Presque tout le commerce d'esportation est entre les mains d'Europeens ; les termes de paiement sont au comptant contre documents, ou bien d'un a trois mois de credit ; lorque l'acquereaur traite poir Melbourne, il a or- dinairement un credit en banque a Loundres, sur lequel de vendeur est libre de faire traite.

L'industrie de la confiserie principalement emploie la gomme arabique ; inais ce prduit set egalement dans nombre d'autres industries, comme celles des produits chimiques, de l'impression et de la teinture.

Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaust- ive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statustics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). div.head: TELEGRAMS.
THE CASABLANCA TROUBLE. AN IMPROVED SITUATION. THE GROWTH OF ANARCHY.
div.p: The country surrounding Casa Blanca was decribed on Tuesday as swarming with mounted arabs, advancing on the town indiffer- ent to shells from the warship. The Moors on Wednesday morning furiously attacked the British Consulate, firing from loopholed Moor- ish houses. 30 of Galilee's bluejackets defend- ed it in the bravest manner, making sorties. The arrival of 4 French warships and transports with Algerian troops at noon relieved them most opportunely.
It is stated that about 3000 Moors attacked the French General Drude outside Casa Blanca, but soon retired with heavy losses caused by artillery.(Reuter)

It is recognised that the Algeciras Conven- tion is inadequate to meet the growing anarchy in Morocco. The impression is growing that a considerable force of troops, instead of police, will be necessary to restore order. The Spanish Government has decided to send more troops. The comments in the German press are strikingly calm and reserved. (R.)

An improvement is apparent at Casa Blanca, Rabat, and Mazagan. The Sultan has expressed his refrets for the attack against the French, and has offered to give satisfaction. It is reported that 4000 Moors were killed at Casa Blanca.(Havas)

The French Admiral Philibert reported on 9th instant that the situation at Casablanca was unchanged. He praises the devotion of the sister of the British Consul at Mazagan who is tending the wounded at Casablanca. (Later). Admiral Philibert reports that the Moors have been attempting night attacks at Casablanca. A fierce attack took place yes- terday afternoon which was brilliantly re- pulsed. A steamer which left Casablanca yesterday reports that French cavalry and artillery are within 10 kilometres of the town. Terrible destruction has been wrought among the na- tives. the stench of the bodies in the streets is awful and an epidemic is fears. 400 refugees from Casa Blanca, mostly Jews, have arrived here in a most pitiable condition. (Reuter)

The towns of Mazagari and Rabat are calm. There is no further development at Casa Blanca. No house is undamaged an the roads are eneumbered by the dead. Some attacks were attempted during the night.(Havas)

div.head: A MARSEILLES MYSTERY.
AN IRISH COUPLE ARRESTED
div.p: Mr. and Mrs. Vere Goold, belonging to a good Irish family, have been arrested here with the dismembered corpse of a woman in one of their trunks. It has been ascertained that the body is that of Madame Levin with whom the Goolds were acquainted at Monte Carlo. They are accused of murdering the lady for the sake of her valuable jewels. Mr. Goold's brother is a baronet, and is working as a ganger on a railway in South Australia. (Reuter)

div.head: EVICTED TENANTS BILL.
THE LORDS' AMENDMENTS.
div.p: House of Lords.-The committee have made several important amendments to the Evicted Tenants Bill despite the resistance of the Government. It is understood that the latter refuse to accept the amendements. (R.)

div.head: TELEGRAMS.
JAPAN AND KOREA.
TWO GARRISON MUTINY.
div.p: Marquis Ito and 8 members of the Japanese Koreau administration have gone to Tokio. Three members of the Marquis's staff have been appointed Korean vice-ministers.(R.)

div.head: STRIKES IN AMERICA.
TELEGRAPH OPERATORS CEASE WORK.
div.p: 1600 telegraph operators have gone on on strike here in sympathy with the strikers in Denver, Kansas, and Salt Late City. Serious developments are feared. (Reuter)

div.head: PEKIN-PARIS RACE.
PRINCE'S VICTORIOUS RIDE.
div.p: Prince Borghese has arrived. He received an ovation.(Reuter)
Prince Borghese has arrived, and was received with great ovations on the conclusion of his successful Pekin-Paris ride.(Havas)

div.head: THE PERSIAN FRONTIER.
VIOLATION BY TURKEY.
div.p: Mr. Isvolsky, Minister of Foreign Affairs, has telegraphed to Mr. Zinovieff to make representations to the Porte on the subject of the violation of the Persian frontier by the Turkish troops. Mr. Zinovieff has replied that Turkey rejects all responsibility for this viola- tion.(Havas)

As a result of the action of the Persian Ambassador, supported by Sir Nicolas O'Conor and M. Zinovieff, the despatch of Turkish reinforcements towards the frontier has been sent to enquire on the spot. Turkey and Persia will punish the respective culprits.(R.)

The American Ambassador has drawn the attention of Porte to the danger the American missionaries are in Urmia. He argues the Porte to prevent the extension of the Turco-Persian frontier trouble, pointing out the consequence should missionaries suffer.(Reuter)

div.head: STRIKE OF TELEGRAPHISTS.
div.p: The telegraphists strike has spread to 50 cities in the Western and Southern States. The operators at San Francisco and here con- template joining the strikers.(Reuter)

div.head: THE TROUBLE IN BELFAST.
div.p: A mob stoned a party of the Berkshire Regiment engaged in guarding carts, and seriously injured an officer. (Reuter)

div.head: JAPAN AND KOREA.
div.p: The garrisons of Honju and Wonju have mutinied. The Japanese cavalry pursuing the, former has been routed. The outbreak at Wonju is serious the rioters have been rein- forced by Korean troops and have put the Japanese officers to flight. Japanese troops have been despatched to Wonju.(Reuter)

div.head: COLONEL ELLIOT'S ESCAPE.
div.p: The escape of Colonel Elliot was a remark- able exploit. His captors omitted to search him and he succeeded in freeing himself of his bonds and drew a revolver and shot 3 guards, then two more, who were barring his flight. (Reuter)

div.head: SERIOUS TRAIN COLLISION.
div.p: The southern express to Madrid ran into a train, and set fire to the Otsaurte tunnel. It is reported that the tunnel has fallen in. (Havas)

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE
div.p: The Powers have agreed upon the question of a permanent tribunal of arbitration. (Havas)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: Notts beat Gloucester by 2 wickets. Lauca- shire beat Kent by 87 runs. Essex beat Sussex by 2 wickets. The following matches have been drawn: Yorkshire v. Warwickshire and Surrey v. Middlesex.(Reuter)

div.head: CASABLANCA.
THE SCENE OF THE MASSACRES.
div.p: The massacre of a number of Europeans by the fanatical Moorish tribesmen brings to the notice of the general reader on the busiest and most thriving towns on the nort-west coast of Africa-thriving, that is, in the Moorish and not the English sense. As in China, so in Morocco, foreigners are only per- mitted to land at certain Treaty ports ; to attempt to get ashore anywhere else involves the certainty of being fired upon in the most unceremonious fashion by the jealous natives. It is very strange that in the twentieth centure when the world generally has made such vast strides in civilisation, there should still be at our very doors-within a couple of days' steaming from Plymouth-a country in which sich exclusiveness and fana- ticism still prevail. The natives of Tangier, Larasch, Casablanca, Mazagan, and Mogador have long been in constant communication with Europeans, quite a large number of whom have resided in these towns for many years, and yet there is no real sympathy between the two races, so that the moment there is the least prospect of trouble between them the Moors are fully prepared, when the signal is given, to pounce upon and cut the throats of any foreigners they come across. This jealousy of foreigners and all their works has prevented the introduction of any modern ideas into the country. There are neither railways nor docks, indeed, there are no roads as we understand the word. It is the arrangement for constructing a harbour that has excited the wrath of the Moors round Casablanca and led to the recent regrettable incident. To the natives the town is Dar-el-Beida, built by the Portugese some 300 or 400 years ago, and by them named Casablanca-the White House-but all houses in Morocco are white Casablanca is one of the principal ports of the country, because it is the nearest coast town to the City of Mo- rocco, and it has, therefore, been customary when the Sultan sends missions to foreign countries for officials to use Casablanca as the port of embarkation and debarkation rather than Tangier or Mogador. The picturesque Embassy which came to London to congratulate Kind Edward on his accession to the Throne travelled via Casablanca. So also did Sid Ab- derrahman Ben Abder-Saddick with his reti- nue, who has been deputed by the Sultan to attend the Coronation which was to have been performed in June, 1902. He explained to an interviewer that he has greatly enjoyed his visit to this country, "but," he added, "I shall be glad to get back to civilisation !" The civi- lisation of Casablanca, in the estimation of our distinguished visitor, is superior to that of Western London. Of course in civilisation, as in other things, tastes differ. Casablanca is certainly not the place where, from choice, a civilised human being, with superior and refined tastes, would voluntarily select as a desirable residence for a lifetime. The English and other foreigners, to the num- ber of 200 or 300, who live there are either in the Consular service or actively engaged in trade. Owing to the exposure to the Atlantic there is no docking accommodation down the West Coast of Africa, from the Strait of Gibraltar to Table Bay, the nearest approach to a harbour being off Mogador, where ships lie at anchor between the town and Mogador island, the latter, however, affording little or no protection. An incessant Atlantic swell rolls in and breaks with more or less violence on the unprotected coast. The Morocco ports are nothing more than open roadsteads, and in consequence of the never ceasing swell, vessels are compelled to come to anchor at some distance out in the offing. All business with the shore has to be conducted by means of boats rowed by bodies of sturdy natives, who, however, sometimes find it impossible to venture out against the high breaking swell. This tends to hamper trade to an appreci- able extend, for passengers and merchandise must be conveyed to and fro by means of the surf boats. Off Casablanca, due to a combination of circumstances-the heavy swell, the full nature of the sea bottom on near- in the town, and the general drift of the current, which here sets in towards the land-the anchorage is at a distance of from three-quarters of a mile to two miles from the town, so it can be easily understood that the trade of the district cannot be enormous. As seen from the see the town, which is walled round, occupies a fairly picturesque situation, but the surrounding country is rather tame, generally flat and uninteresting. The towers of the various

mosques stand out prominently, onr of them rising to probably 150ft. To the right is the fort, surmounted by a conspicious tower, and beyond the wall, about midway be- tween the fort and the port of entrance gate, floats the flag over the British Con- sulate, where Mr. Allan Maclean, nephew of Sir Harry Maclean, now in the hands of Raisuli, the rebel chief, looks after our interests in this part of Morocco. As an instance of the high state of civilisation of the country it may be mentioned that with the exception of Lloyd's splendid light- house on Cape Spartel, the north-western extremity of Africa, there is no recognised lighthouse along a distance of 1,500 miles down the African coast from Tangier, but some two or three years since one of the merchants at Casablanca erected a small stand on the roof of his warehouse, on which a light in occasionally exhibited for the benefit of shipping. Persons going ashore have to be quick in their movements when boarding the surf boats, for these are tossed up and down like corks on the heaving sea, and it is not uncommon for the waves to break on board during the journey shoreward. The boats run aground within a couple of yards or so of the shore, near the port gate, and by means of a plank the visitor is able to step right into the midst of a busy a scene as many business man could desire to see. The beach is piled high with merchandise reasy to be despatched to the ships rolling about uneasily in the distance of already brought ashore from them. There is no tramway; no mechanical aids, no waggons or carts, not even the simple hand barrow. Every task has to be performed in the most primitive manner, by human labour-building the Pyramids of Egypt over again. A small army of swarthy porters-strapping Moorish and negro giants, over six feet high, and apparently possessed of the strength of lions-hurrying to and fro between the landing place and the warehouses, groan under their heavy burdens. Through the confused heaps of merchandise and the crowd of noisy people, old and young, and dodging the continuous stram of porters, the visitor finds his way to the Port gate and gains ad- mission into the town. Inside he finds he has to be quite as cautious in threading his way about, for even the Regent-Street of Casablanca is not many feet broad, yet it is strewn with great bales of wool, skins, stacks of corn, maize, beans, and other things, while here and there the way is blocked by a camel or two taking a much-needed rest. There is no vestry or town council to look after the sanitation of the place, with its population variously estimated at from 8,000 to 20,000. The streets are unswept, and the public health, which is considered good, is left to Nature herself - a powerful sun, a dry wind, and a sandy soil. The market in on the way to the Rabat, or north gate. Here the bales of merchandise give way to the more modest wares of the street merchants-fruits and sweets of many kinds, baskets of eggs, and an endless variety of marketable goods. The joints of meat present a repulsive appearance, and to the eye of the Londoner many other things in the market look as if the sanitary inspector should take promt action, but here nobody interferes, everything is left to be attacked by myriads of flies, which darken the air and enjoy them- selves on all the dainties exposed for sale. Passing out of the Rabat gate it is at once evident where all the supplies for the market have come. Overnight a great caravan of tra- ders arrived from the interior, and their camp- ing ground is on the sandy plain outside the town, where are found scorse of hundreds of camels, and flocks of sheep and goats, loads of dates, and other things. The wealth- ier European merchants have erected for themselves comfortable houses at a little distance to the eastward of the town, where they cultivate whatever can be grown in the way of fruit and flowers. In the midst of the hot and dirty town the traveller finds a perfect haven of rest in an exceedingly comfortable

English club-house, the resort, of course, of the European residents in the neighborhood. Naturally, consequent upon the transport difficulties, the trade of the district if not nearly so valuable as it might be were greater facilities available. As it is, the exports amount to about 300,000 per annum, and the imports to about 250,000. These figures could be enourmously increased, as any quantity of corn can be grown for exporation, and with a little judicious supervision the present primitive methods of cultivation, which are sufficient for the immediate needs of the country, could make way for the introduction of more modern scientific farming, requiring the importation of machinery on a wholesale scale. It is the deter- mination of the French to force upon the town a harbour-in itself a very necessary improve- ment-that has brought about the disaster which now threatens to bring further trouble in its train. The natives were not yet ready for such an immense change, for which a little education and persuasion were necessary, for the Moors are keen traders, and they could have been brought round to realise that they would in the end greatly benefit, financially and otherwise, by the construction of a harbour as Casablanca. ("Morning Post").
